byline.contributor: Melissa Eddy contributed reporting from Berlin, and Liz Alderman from Athens.

abstract: Negotiations over bailout package being worked out between Greece and its creditors, third such measure in five years, have revealed stark divisions over who is morally at fault for situation and how to amend it; involved parties have been resistant to economists' insistence that morals are of little use in situation governed by hard numbers.
lead_paragraph: Nearly all agree that Greece’s debt is unsustainably high, but figuring out how to grapple with it has unleashed a volatile mix of politics, economics, history and even morality.

headline.main: Personalities Clashing Over How to Handle New Greek Bailout
headline.print_headline: Personalities Clashing Over New Greek Bailout

snippet: Nearly all agree that Greece’s debt is unsustainably high, but figuring out how to grapple with it has unleashed a volatile mix of politics, economics, history and even morality.
